bestBHT.bht: The mention of took a wife and married highlights the significance of marriage. Interestingly, the ancient Jews understood seed as referring to an individual, a view also shared by the Sadducees. This differs from the modern interpretation of seed in discussions about Genesis 3:15. These insights deepen our understanding of the broader context of marriage in the Bible, showcasing the various interpretations of terminology.

Archibald T. Robertson: Took a wife (ελαβεν γυναικα). So Luke 20:29. Matthew has "married" (γημας).
John Gill: No child: hence it is clear that the ancient Jews used the word seed, of a single person, as these Sadducees did.
Though modern ones deny such an use of it in our present controversies with them about the sense of Genesis 3:15.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 12:20, the phrase took a wife is also mentioned in Luke 20:29, while Matthew uses the term married. These different phrasings highlight the importance of marriage in this context. Furthermore, the mention of the word seed indicates that ancient Jews referred to a single person as seed, which is also the case with the Sadducees. This understanding of the term seed contrasts with the modern interpretation in our controversies regarding the sense of Genesis 3:15, which speaks of the seed of the woman.

The mention of took a wife in the verse, along with its alternative expression married, highlights the significance of marriage. It is interesting to note that the ancient Jews used the word seed to refer to a single person, which aligns with the view of the Sadducees. This contrasts with the modern interpretation of seed in our controversies surrounding Genesis 3:15. These insights deepen our understanding of the verse and the broader concept of marriage in biblical contexts.

The phrase took a wife in Mark 12:20, similar to Luke 20:29, and Matthew's use of married, emphasize the significance of marriage. Interestingly, the ancient Jews understood seed to refer to an individual, just as the Sadducees did. This differs from the modern interpretation of seed in the ongoing debates about Genesis 3:15. These insights enrich our understanding of the broader context of marriage within the Bible, shedding light on the diverse interpretations of related terminology.

The various phrasings of took a wife and married in this passage highlight the significance of marriage. It is intriguing how the ancient Jews understood the term seed to refer to an individual, aligning with the perspective of the Sadducees. The disparity arises when comparing this ancient understanding to the modern interpretation of seed in the ongoing discussions concerning Genesis 3:15. These insights enhance our comprehension of the broader context of marriage within the biblical narrative, revealing the divergent interpretations of terminology.
